newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS - Volatility expected to increase.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS - Volatility expected to increase.

text.p: Volatility in U.S. stock indices has slipped over the last several days as volumes declined ahead of key economic data, but analysts said volatility will likely increase from Friday on.

The key U.S. employment report for October is scheduled for release Friday before the market opens. Nonfarm payrolls are expected to increase by 212,000 according to a Reuters poll, compared with a decline of 40,000 in September.
"The numbers are so important and unless they are right at expectations, which is unlikely, you'll see some sort of reaction," said Chris Cadbury at Cadbury Fax Service.
Cadbury said the high level of pessimism suggests that whatever the numbers, the market is likely to move higher.

"There's a fair amount of pessimism around," he said. "A lot of puts have been trading relative to calls. My work gave a buy signal on the Nasdaq on Tuesday and we're approaching that on the overall market."
At 1035 CST (1635 GMT), the Nasdaq composite index .IXIC was up about five points at 1,211. The blue chip Dow industrial average .DJI was ahead 13 at 6,006.
Among broader indices, the S&P 100 was up 1.22 at 676.82 and the S&P 500 added 1.16 to 702.06
Todd Salamone, senior analyst at Investment Research Institute in Cincinnati, said put premiums have risen over the last few days in anticipation of more volatility.
In particular, the Chicago Board Options Exchange's (CBOE) volatility index has risen through the 20 level from a recent low around 16, he said.
At 1035 CST (1635 GMT), the VIX was up 0.48 at 19.86, having reached an intraday peak at 20.19, its highest level since September 5.
Cadbury said while volatility and volume are likely to increase, any rally may not push the market much higher.
"It looks like we're going to go up for a bit but then we have to see if cash starts coming into (mutual) funds. It didn't last week," he said.
If investors continue to hold back new fund purchases, "the rally will be probably like a two percent variety rather than five percent or more type," he said.
Salomone said the market may get a boost early next week in the wake of next Tuesday's U.S. presidential election.
A consensus has developed that if the Democrats win the presidency and regain control of one house of Congress, the market may sell off, he said.
"If it happens, the initial reaction could be negative since there's already talk it will happen," Salamone said.

"If a lot of it is factored into the market already and you don't have that sweep, I think you will get a rally," he added. "But certainly talk is you're going to get a negative jolt on a Democratic sweep."
In morning trading Thursday, stock index options trading continued its recent thin trend, with the underlying indices bouncing around unchanged, traders said.
